departmentDescription: The mission of the Media Studies Program is to enable students to become astute scholars, producers, and consumers of visual media. From film to TV to digital and social media, our worlds are saturated with and mediated by visual communications. Media Studies courses equip students with: 1) critical tools for critiquing visual media, 2) creative capabilities for producing digital art, and 3) practical communication skills for participating in globalized media networks. Interdisciplinary by design, the Media Studies Program is supported by faculty from three divisions—Fine Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences—in order to cover media theories and practices in the broadest sense and stress digital literacy and fluency across multiple media. Its forward-thinking approach emphasizes interdisciplinarity, a globalized curriculum, and career readiness.

courses: MST 202: Topics in Media Studies OR Art 102: Intro to Digital Art (4 credits)
MST 385: Film and Media Theory (4 credits)
MST 485: Senior Seminar in Media Studies (4 credits)
You must have one of the two concentrations:
Film Studies: Various courses from different departments focusing on film studies
Media Production:Various art courses and courses related to media production
Courses from the other Media Studies concentration

Various other elective courses related to media studies, including anthropology, sociology, art, English, history, international studies, media studies, philosophy, politics and law, Russian, Spanish, and urban studies
16 out of 40 credits should be at the 300 or 400 level.
8 out of 40 credits must be in courses that focus on media outside the US.
Three additional courses from a list of offerings in various departments
One of these requirements may be satisfied by a directed inquiry or an internship (on approval of the Media Studies Committee).
